Wrong, and wrong.

The term "counter" in this context is based on the term "counteract." When two things counteract each other, **they cancel each other out.** Even in games where "counter" is referring to a "counter attack," they are usually, at best, a combat equalizer (he struck you, you struck him, you both lost ~10 HP each).

An actual counter would mean that, when played right and on a perfectly even playing field (which is an idealization that won't happen, but still), neither one should actually be capable of killing the other without dying/nearly dying themselves.

The kind of counter you seek is what is known as a hard counter; something that unquestionably, irrefutably destroys the thing weak to it. And Riot's kind of been moving *away* from hard counters, considering how binary they can make a game.

I appreciate what you're saying, but I think it's just arguing semantics.  In the League community, 'counter' is used to denote a champion that overwhelms the one you're currently playing.  When someone says, 'Oh no, they counter me', do you seriously believe they mean, 'Oh no, they go perfectly even with me'?  That's not how it's used here.  There are advantageous lanes, where your champion has the edge; even matchups/skill matchups; and then 'counterpicks' which give you an inherit advantage over the opponent you're facing.

You can disagree if you want, but I can guarantee that when people in the community call a champion a 'counter' to their mains, they don't mean 'that champion is perfectly equal in strength, without any advantage over me whatsoever'.  They mean their kit has an advantage over yours.  That is how it is used in the context of League, regardless of which dictionary definition you choose to use.

Keep in mind that your definition of counters would mean that whatever you counter also counters you.  That two champions both counterpick eachother at the same time.  There's obviously some logic that doesn't follow here.

But again, you can use whatever definition you want.

Yes, when someone in the community is referring to a counter-pick, they are talking about a champion that has an advantage against them, but *very rarely is that advantage something they cannot play around.*

This is the difference in League of Legends; counter-play, or the ability to *outplay* another player, is what equalizes counter-picks being "stronger" than the champions they counter.

Sure, Alistar and Leona are both nightmares against Katarina, but that doesn't mean she can't time her spells in combat to avoid her ultimate being interrupted. Yes, a lot of mid-lane mages are easy targets for Zed, but they can interrupt his ultimate, which is realistically his only way to guarantee a kill if he doesn't have a huge lead.

I could continue with specific cases, but the general idea is that counter-picks are not guaranteed to counter an opponent. The player's level of skill, and their team's ability to work together, should always have more of an effect than a counter-pick.

So as a preface, I do not really have an opinion about the hit box of Thresh's hook. That being said giving anecdotal evidence is not really proof of balance or lack thereof. As I understand this there could be two explanations for this happening.

One there actually is a disparity of hit-boxes with Twisted Fate, Thresh's hook, or both resulting in hooks landing when visuals would say they should not. 

Two the game does not constantly calculate game state changes. While it does so at regular intervals (.25 seconds for most updates if memory serves) there are moments where game states are changing in between calculations. In these screen shots the hook is being thrown while the two champs are almost in melee range. This could also be a rare case of game state calculations deciding the hooks was landing at a calculation interval but movement occurred between calculations making the hook look like a miss.

Without more information on several factors that went into this picture it is hard to infer anything about the actually balance of Thresh's hook hit-box.
